{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3488508,"name":"Dhyan Soni","username":"dhyansoni","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/d/a4c791/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-01-20T22:27:02.615Z","cooked":"

Our team is exploring SysID as a method to tune kA and other elements to get a baseline of our feedforward and PID values, but we are not getting what we expected. We have a large overshoot, and the kA value seems far lower than it should be as we are both lagging behind our velocity setpoints and not applying a full 12 volts to catch up (in fact, it is only applying around 5). Notably, the kV value seems to be precise and is working quite well. Here are some of the specifics of how we are approaching this tool.

ElevatorSim
Currently, we are using the ElevatorSim class as our subsystem to characterize.

SysID
Looking through the docs we found a SysIdRoutine class and a few ways to run the two tests: quasistatic and dynamic. The code is below.

Elevator.java

routine1261×550 42.1 KB

Config Numbers

  • Max ramp rate: 1.2
  • Step voltage: 12
  • Seconds: 10

The testing pattern we used was to run quasistatic kForward then kReverse then dynamic kForward and kReverse. We waited for around 10 seconds for each. Then load the DataLog onto SysId. We got values that “worked” but have a lot of overshoot. Notably, kA did not move its value besides extremely minute changes.

Questions

Has anyone gotten more accurate results from SysId?

If yes,

  1. Is the process + code we are using currently, correct for SysId characterization?
  2. Why is the kA value off by so much & how to make it change

On a side note, if anyone has any suggestions on an alternative way to find kA that would be much appreciated!

dhyansoni:

On a side note, if anyone has any suggestions on an alternative way to find kA that would be much appreciated!

You can hand calc kA directly from theory.

From the point of the motor before any gear reductions or conversion to linear motion, kA is almost exactly
k_a = \frac{J_{effective}}{k_t * gearratio}
Where J_{effective} is the effective moment of inertia at the motor, and k_t is the torque constant which can be found here.

dhyansoni:

Without PID

Can you zoom in on the X axis so we can see the time scale? If the PID is being ran on the rio, this behavior is explainable by latency which destabilizes controllers, even more so if they are fast, like lets say an elevator that moves in around 0.5s.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":13,"updated_at":"2025-01-20T22:53:45.531Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":5,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":5,"reads":228,"readers_count":227,"score":70.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":482797,"topic_slug":"sysid-pid-and-feedfoward-tuning-for-elevator","display_username":"Dhyan Soni","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":50219,"username":"Alex_Y","name":"","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/82dd89/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":71548,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/sysid-pid-and-feedfoward-tuning-for-elevator/482797/6","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3488845,"name":"usbcd36","username":"usbcd36","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/usbcd36/{size}/2444_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-21T13:17:16.072Z","cooked":"

The great thing about a simulation is that you can just try out values and see what happens; can’t damage a simulated elevator. SysID is great for getting close, but if you think kA might be too small, test that hypothesis; boost kA and see what happens.

Consider that your ultimate goal is probably to get a tuned elevator for competition; SysID is merely a tool to help reach that; if it’s not giving you complete and perfect results, you can do some manual tuning afterwards. Also, if you eventually find good tuning parameters, you might be able to work backwards to figure out why SysID isn’t giving you those before you get to the real elevator.

These plots (all aligned in time with position) will provide more insight into your current tuning parameters:

  • velocity setpoint
  • velocity
  • PID controller output
  • feedforward output

How do you start simulations? I don’t want to break anything on my robot if I use SysID, and I also want to be able to get as much done while I wait on my builders.

Thank you! It does seem like SysId is useful for certain tuning parameters (kV & kG especially), boosting kA seems to provide the desired result. We have found certain good tuning parameters by manual tuning, but can’t figure out why SysId isn’t providing those results.

We start the simulations using the routines provided by SysiD, inputing our own setVoltage methods to allow SysId essentianlly to run its own tests. Then running those routines with button bindings. I detailed how we run the tests in my original message.

dhyansoni:

On a side note, if anyone has any suggestions on an alternative way to find kA that would be much appreciated!

Assuming you are doing a smooth motion profile for input command… A “tune knobs to taste” approach:

  1. Start with fairly slow maximum velocity and maximum acceleration. 0.3 for both is a good guess.
  2. Set Kg, Kv, Ka, Kp, Ki, and Kd to zero.
  3. Increase Kg as much as you can without the elevator moving upward. You will have to zero in on Kg fairly precisely (at least two decimal places).
  4. Increase the velocity feedforward gain Kv until the straight segments of the elevator actual motion have the same slope as the desired motion.
  5. Increase the acceleration feedforward gain Ka until the curved segments of the elevator actual motion have the same curvature as the desired motion.

Practice here:

FIRST Robotics Competition Documentation

Tuning a Vertical Elevator with Motion Profiling

In this section, we will tune a simple position controller for a vertical elevator. In addition, we will discuss the advantages of using motion profiling for this situation. About the Profiler: A M...

dhyansoni:

Without PID

Looking at this graph, a few observations:

1)In steady-state, (zero change in height command) your elevator is drifting upward. Whatever you’re doing to compensate for gravity is too strong.
2) Zoom in a bit more on the rising edge of the no-PID - double check whether the slopes of the actual/desired position are matching. It looks close but hard to say from a distance.
3) Plot out commanded voltage as well. I’m curious if you’re saturating at 12v at any point. It’s curious that around 3 seconds (start of motion) the elevator starts moving very quickly, but around 3.8 seconds (end of motion) the motion continues for quite some time after the command stops. It almost looks like gravity is inverted (helps at the start, hinders at the end… when it should be the opposite). Not saying it actually is, just looks like it.
